Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Sculpting Electric Machines for Unidirectional Motion

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to study the improvement in electric machine operation when unidirectional motion is taken into account, since the vast majority of generators and motors rotate in a single direction. The approach is to precisely sculpt the stator and rotor surfaces, thus affecting the electromagnetic field in the air gap so that the production of electromechanical torque is increased. The transformative value of this approach rests in its generality, being applicable to rotating machines of any power rating, material, or type.

This research will involve analysis using the electromagnetic finite element method embedded inside an optimization loop, by adapting shape sensitivity-based design methods. This work is important because (1) it will advance our understanding of electromechanical energy conversion; (2) it will lead to generic methodologies for obtaining optimal machine designs; and (3) it involves multidisciplinary research in electric machines, power electronics, numerical computation, and optimization.

This research will result in lighter-weight, more efficient, and more cost-effective solutions for electromechanical energy conversion for virtually all generation and motion applications. Hence, its overall environmental and economical impact will be tremendous. The project will contribute to the education of power engineers at the undergraduate and graduate levels, and a conscious effort will be made to recruit underrepresented students. Additionally, the PI will establish mentoring relationships with local high-school students. A series of distance education courses, short courses, and seminars will be developed. Finally, the research insights and results will be integrated into a textbook on optimal electric machine design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vast majority of electric machines rotate in a single direction over the span of their lifetimes, but this operational characteristic is not being taken advantage of during their design. Improved designs lead to enhanced performance for a preferred direction of rotation, or more precisely, for a preferred direction of torque production. To this end, this project initiated research in optimally designing asymmetric electric machines. In particular, this was achieved by precisely "sculpting" the stator and rotor inner surfaces, thus affecting the electromagnetic field inside the machine, so that the level and quality of electromagnetic torque is increased without otherwise compromising the machine’s electrical operational characteristics. The transformative value of this approach rests in its generality. It can be applied to rotating machines of any size, material, power rating, or type, since its main hypothesis exploits a principle of physics common to all.

In this effort, our research focused on improving the performance of switched reluctance motors, which are commonly encountered in electric vehicle traction applications. We developed optimization algoirithms and metrics for studying and quantifying the improvement in operation of such motors. Our findings strongly indicate that significant performance gains can be obtained by simultaneously sculpting the stator and rotor teeth in these machines. These improvements can lead to lighter-weight, more efficient, less noisy, and more cost-effective solutions for electric vehicles and wind energy generation. 

The work was completed by two graduate students at Iowa State University, Ames, Iowa, and at Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana. The graduate students presented their work in professional conferences. Throughout the project, we employed several undergraduate research assistants in various roles. We also had the opportunity to host high-school students in our laboratory, who learned about the role of machines and power electronics in renewable energy applications. In addition, we have created a Facebook group open to anyone who is broadly interested in electric power systems and smart grids.
